newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot natgas prices strengthen on cold weather.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot natgas prices strengthen on cold weather.

text.p: U.S. spot natgas prices rebounded on Monday as a cold front moved into the central U.S., thereby putting a strain on supplies, industry sources said.
Gulf Coast prices climbed about five cents to the mid-to-high $2.30s, with Henry Hub, La., quoted mostly in the $2.38-2.41 range.
Prices were equally higher in south Texas in the $2.35-$2.37 range despite Texas Utilities' full restoration of its 1,150 megawatt Comanche Peak nuclear unit 2.
With the thermometer gradually falling, prices in the Midcontinent also gained about four to five cents to the high-$2.20s.
The Chicago city-gate market was quoted in the high-$2.60s to mid-$2.70s, while prices on Northern at Demarcation wavered in the $2.30-2.40 range.
In west Texas, colder temperatures in Northwest caused Permian prices to jump into the mid-$2.20s, up more than five cents from Friday's levels.
As Canadian exports into the U.S. dwindled because of the cold weather now in western Canada, prices at the southern California border surged into the $2.30s, up more than 10 cents from Friday.
Forecasters said temperatures in the Midwest will be as much as 15 degrees below normal on Tuesday. However, temperatures are expected to moderate by the latter part of the week.
